author: By New York Times Audio
title: ‘The Headlines’ in the A.M. Will Return Soon
description: Hear about our new afternoon spinoff.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Nazaryan
title: The Blind Ambition of Chris Christie
description: The former New Jersey governor is a uniquely flawed foil for Donald Trump, compromised in ways that blunt his most effective attacks.
content: Chris Christie’s presidential announcement at a June town hall at Saint Anselm College in New Hampshire may not have had the drama of, say, a “West Wing” episode, but it did help clarify our current political moment and its most intriguing character. For over two hours — you could turn it into a mini-series — Mr. Christie, a former New Jersey governor and federal prosecutor, built a case against Donald Trump. To nominate him for the presidency again, Mr. Christie said, would be a moral and political disaster. “Trump made us smaller,” Mr. Christie told his audience as he prowled the stage, explaining that he wanted to go after Mr. Trump for two reasons: “One, he deserves it. And two, it’s the way to win.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: If Trump Trial Isn’t Broadcast Live, a Plea to Record It for Posterity
description: A request to broadcast one of Donald Trump’s federal trials made an intriguing backup argument, one rooted not in the news cycle but in ensuring a complete historical record.
content: In a pair of filings this month, news organizations asked a federal judge in Washington to allow live television coverage of the trial of President Donald J. Trump on charges that he conspired to undermine the 2020 election. They face a distinctly uphill fight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: No Longer Scotland’s Leader, Sturgeon Focuses on Learning to Drive
description: The former first minister, who resigned and quit as leader of the Scottish National Party before her arrest in June, said seeking a driver’s license at 53 had taken her out of her comfort zone.
content: Scotland’s former first minister, Nicola Sturgeon, who unexpectedly resigned this year and later became the subject of a police investigation, made another unusual announcement on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: How High Interest Rates Sting Bakers, Farmers and Consumers
description: Everyone who relies on credit in America is confronting a new reality: Money will cost more for a good long while.
content: Home buyers, entrepreneurs and public officials are confronting a new reality: If they want to hold off on big purchases or investments until borrowing is less expensive, it’s probably going to be a long wait.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: War With Hamas Hits Israel’s Economy, Central Bank Says
description: The debt and deficit are expected to jump as the country raises military spending and increases support for businesses and civilians.
content: The war between Israel and Hamas will abruptly slow the Israeli economy this year and next and send the nation’s budget deficit soaring as the country ramps up spending to support the military, civilians and businesses during the conflict, the Bank of Israel said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman and Alan Yuhas
title: Israel Intensifies Strikes on Gaza as Its Allies Call for More Palestinian Aid
description: As two more hostages are released, American officials have urged Israel to delay a ground invasion, to allow time for negotiations and for more humanitarian aid to enter Gaza.
content: Israel’s military struck hundreds of targets in Gaza on Monday, in one of the biggest barrages yet of its war with Hamas and as a trickle of aid arrived for desperate Palestinians in the strip, where the lack of clean water, medicine and other critical supplies is fueling a dire humanitarian crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Alex Stern, Eric Krupke, Summer Thomad, Jessica Cheung, Sydney Harper, Marc Georges, Lisa Chow, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: The Problem With a $2 Trillion Deficit
description: The growing deficit has been at the center of the fight over choosing a House speaker.
content: Over a year, the federal deficit — the gap between what the U.S. government spends and what it earns — has doubled, to nearly $2 trillion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Tuesday Briefing: Israel Intensifies Gaza Strikes
description: Plus the worldwide popularity of Lionel Messi’s pink jersey.
content: The death toll in Gaza rose sharply yesterday, according to the Hamas-run health ministry, after Israel said it had struck hundreds of targets in the territory in one of the biggest barrages of airstrikes in recent days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Kirby
title: Three Poetry Books That Take the Measure of Life, and Death
description: In different ways, Saskia Hamilton’s “All Souls,” Robyn Schiff’s “Information Desk” and Major Jackson’s “Razzle Dazzle” contend with the creative impulse and the human condition.
content: The poems that engage us are often ones that don’t seem to know they’re poems; it’s as though no one ever told them, “Hey, you’re a poem — start acting like one!” Not for Saskia Hamilton the measured rollout of the traditional lyric: Instead, the four longish poems that make up ALL SOULS (Graywolf, 86 pp., paperback, $17) start when and where they want to, go where they will, break off in what should have been a middle but isn’t, and then not stop, exactly, but disappear, like the little blips and half-signals that were transmitted by Amelia Earhart as she flew … where?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Visitors Will Be Able to See Prospect Park’s Waterfall. Eventually.
description: Fallkill Falls has long been officially off limits. That’s changing, but parkgoers may have to wait until winter to see actual water falling.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday, and I’m filling in for James Barron. Today we’ll visit a part of Prospect Park that has been off limits (at least officially) for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Review: These Art-Historical Nudes Become Bodies in Time
description: Spare and simple, “Aging Prelude” at the Chocolate Factory is a new beginning for the choreographic duo Chameckilerner.
content: Nine naked people pose on a grassy lawn, like statues in a sculpture garden: standing, sitting, squatting, reclining in stillness. The light is warm, and bright but melancholy music plays. This is the scene that greets you as you enter “Aging Prelude,” a brief and delicately composed new work by the choreographic duo Chameckilerner (Rosane Chamecki and Andrea Lerner), which had its premiere at the Chocolate Factory Theater on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Behind the Editors’ Note on Gaza Hospital Coverage
description: Joe Kahn, the executive editor of The New York Times, speaks to Lulu Garcia-Navarro about The Times’s early coverage of an explosion at a hospital in Gaza City, and where the paper fell short.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: Park Seo-Bo, Whose Quiet Paintings Trumpeted Korean Art, Dies at 91
description: With monochromatic works and the instincts of an avid self-promoter, he helped introduce his country’s art to the world, but not without personal struggle.
content: Park Seo-Bo, a painter whose elegantly furrowed monochromes and indefatigable drive made him a pillar of the Korean art world, died on Oct. 14 in Seoul. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: War Has Smashed Assumptions About Israeli-Palestinian Conflict
description: Some paradigms taken for granted about Israel and the Palestinians, both in Gaza and the West Bank, have been broken. So has the idea that Washington can ignore the Middle East.
content: The sudden and unexpected terror attack by Hamas into Israel has been a crushing blow to a host of assumptions that have defined the Israeli-Palestinian conflict for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: With Their Soldiers Poised to Attack, Israelis Try to Decipher the Delay
description: So pervasive is the pall of chaos in Israel’s government that top officials saw fit to assure a traumatized public that they are “working in close and full cooperation, around the clock.”
content: For 17 days, Israeli ground troops and tanks have been on standby, idling in the dusty fields around Gaza. Their stated mission: to invade the Palestinian coastal enclave and destroy the military capabilities of Hamas, the armed Islamist group, and its ability to rule there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Lauren Jackson
title: A Delayed Invasion
description: Why the U.S. wants Israel to pause a ground invasion in Gaza.
content: For more than a week, an Israeli ground invasion of Gaza has seemed as if it might begin any day. Troops and tanks have crowded the border. Israel has ordered Gazans to evacuate south. The military has showered missiles on Hamas bunkers to weaken the group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Fight for Speaker Reveals Four Types of House Republicans
description: Jim Jordan’s bid showed the power of the ultraconservative faction in Congress.
content: Up until a few weeks ago, no member of the House Freedom Caucus had ever gotten close to becoming House speaker. After Jim Jordan’s bid, it’s hard not to wonder whether a right-wing speakership might be a matter of when and not if.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Secret of America’s Economic Success
description: We’ve done amazingly well, even if people won’t believe it.
content: When Covid-19 struck, the initial economic impact was devastating. Large parts of major economies shut down, both because of official lockdowns and because people feared that in-person interaction would expose them to infection. In the United States, 20 million jobs suddenly disappeared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: ‘5 Families’ and Factions Within Factions: Why the House G.O.P. Can’t Unite
description: The Republican free-for-all for speaker reflects a web of overlapping blocs that have made the party nearly ungovernable.
content: First, House Republicans chose an establishment guy to be their speaker. But the hard right got sick of him and dumped him after nine months. Then they turned to his No. 2, another mainstream conservative, who was promptly blocked. Then they tried an ultraconservative candidate, but mainstream members struck back, quickly killing his candidacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: To Make ‘Fellow Travelers,’ Ron Nyswaner Had to Fall in Love
description: The new drama, which follows a gay romance over several decades, is the first TV series created by the Oscar-winning writer of “Philadelphia."
content: Ron Nyswaner, the Oscar- and Emmy-nominated screenwriter, can still recall a chance meeting on a beach more than 50 years ago. Then a teenager and a self-described “Jesus freak,” he’d come to Ocean City, N.J., to attend a Youth for Christ conference. Late one night, he said, while walking alone, he saw “a gorgeous, muscular guy” across the sand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: ‘Here We Are’ Review: The Last Sondheim, Cool and Impossibly Chic
description: This inventive, beguiling and not quite fully solved puzzle of a show is a worthy and loving farewell to the great musical dramatist.
content: Stephen Sondheim had a genius for genre. Some of his best works were adapted from very niche sources like penny dreadfuls (“Sweeney Todd”), epistolary novels (“Passion”) and Roman comedies (“A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum”). Leaning hard into their specific styles, he mined their expressive potential in songs that could hardly be improved and never sounded alike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Our Beloved Lemony Shrimp and Bean Stew
description: “Made this exactly according to the recipe and it may be the best thing I ever cooked in my life — I’m 71.”
content: One of my favorite literary pastimes is reading your notes in our New York Times Cooking recipes. They’re savvy and full of smart tips and substitutions. They’re often hilarious (“How r y’all having problems with this I am eleven and I can do it easy peasy”) and sometimes poignant (“I hate this dish. I made it for my ex-boyfriend and he left me again. He said it was too salty and he didn’t like my parents.”) For proof that I’m not the only notes stan, here’s an Instagram account dedicated to the pursuit.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Israel’s Moral and Political Dilemmas
description: Responses to columns by Thomas L. Friedman, Nicholas Kristof and Bret Stephens. Also: A Palestinian author; regulating airlines; presidential ballots.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: A New Era of Psychedelics in Oregon
description: The state has pioneered a therapeutic market for psychedelic mushrooms. Researchers are watching with a mix of excitement and unease.
content: In a carpeted office suite, Alex Beck settled onto a mattress and, under the watch of a trained guide, began chomping through a handful of “Pumpkin Hillbilly” mushrooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: ‘Angry and Afraid’: Tensions High in New York Over Israel-Hamas War
description: Recent protests on both sides of the conflict have drawn thousands, and antisemitic and anti-Islamic attacks have added to the sense of unease.
content: Tensions were high in Muslim and Jewish communities around New York City, with impassioned protests and rallies on both sides in recent days drawing thousands as Israel girded for a ground invasion of Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Shortell and Marian Carrasquero
title: Stone by Ancient Stone, Mexico Recovers Its Lost Treasures
description: In recent years Mexico has mounted an ambitious series of investigations and restitution efforts to correct decades of theft and colonial plundering.
content: Mesoamerican archaeologists know it as Monument 9: a 2,600-year-old carving in stone of a jaguar’s gaping face, roughly five feet wide and tall and weighing one ton. Nearly 60 years ago the relic was looted from the ruins of Chalcatzingo, an Olmec site south of modern-day Mexico City, and smuggled into the United States, where it disappeared into a network of private collections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Hawley
title: Lying All the Way to the Bank in ‘America Fantastica’
description: Tim O’Brien’s manic satire follows a disgraced journalist on a criminal road trip through a myth-addled nation.
content: When scientists take a core sample of fiction from the post-Trump era, they will discover American novelists struggling to unpack the political and social repercussions of his reign. Just as historians work to document the facts of the last 10 years, so, too, do novelists try to reveal their meaning. Tim O’Brien’s diagnosis of what ails America in 2023 is “mythomania,” which he defines as an epidemic of lying that swept our nation during the Trump presidency, infecting man and, he writes, bird alike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Thelma Golden Wins Gish Prize
description: The annual prize is given to someone who has “pushed the boundaries of an art form.” Golden, the director and chief curator of the Studio Museum in Harlem, said it was a “total surprise.”
content: Thelma Golden, the director and chief curator of the Studio Museum in Harlem, was awarded the Dorothy and Lillian Gish Prize, the Gish Prize Trust announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Rapid Antarctic Melting Looks Certain, Even if Emissions Goals Are Met
description: It may be too late to halt the decline of the West Antarctic ice shelves, a study found, but climate action could still forestall the gravest sea level rise.
content: At the bottom of the world, the floating edges of one of the enormous ice sheets covering Antarctica are facing an invisible threat, one that could add to rising sea levels around the globe. They are melting from below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Fellow Travelers’ and ‘Winter House’
description: Showtime premieres a new show about a romance in the 1950s. The Bravo reality show is back with a new cast.
content: With network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Oct. 23 - 29. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Michael C. Bender
title: Republicans Grapple With Being Speakerless, but Effectively Leaderless, Too
description: With a speaker fight in the House, concerns about an aging Senate leader and a 2024 front-runner who has the party in a vise grip, some G.O.P. members worry the turmoil could have long-term effects.
content: Kevin McCarthy, the ousted speaker, was making his way through the Capitol when reporters asked what he thought of the chaos consuming House Republicans, who for nearly three weeks have been trying and failing to replace him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz and Michael Levenson
title: Off-Duty Pilot Accused of Trying to Cut the Engines on an Alaska Airlines Flight
description: The flight was diverted to Portland, Ore., because of a “credible security threat” inside the cockpit, the airline said. An off-duty pilot was charged with attempted murder.
content: An off-duty pilot who was in a jump seat in the cockpit of an Alaska Airlines flight on Sunday was charged with more than 80 counts of attempted murder after he tried to cut fuel to the engines, prompting the plane to divert to Portland, Ore., the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Nonunion Workers Are Playing a Big Role in the Autoworkers’ Strike
description: The three U.S. automakers say they are already at a disadvantage to nonunion rivals while labor leaders hope that big gains in negotiations will inspire workers in Southern states to unionize.
content: Tens of thousands of people who work for Toyota in Kentucky, Mercedes-Benz in Alabama or Tesla in Texas are technically not involved in the high-stakes negotiations taking place between labor and management in and around Detroit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta and Jim Tankersley
title: How the Israel-Hamas War Imperils Action Against Global Warming
description: Oil prices could surge. Disagreements between nations could worsen. The conflict complicates already fragile global diplomacy ahead of crucial climate talks.
content: Global efforts to address climate change are already clouded by bitterness and distrust among countries of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Constant Méheut
title: Kill and Be Killed: Ukraine’s Bloody Battlefield Equation
description: The dynamics of Europe’s deadliest war in generations remain exceedingly violent and increasingly complicated by factors far from the battlefield.
content: As Russia mounted wave after wave of attacks over the summer, Sgt. Mykola Rogozovets and fellow members of his unit started drawing little plus signs in the dirt of their bunker while artillery shook the ground around them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: The Doyenne of Classical Publicists Takes on a Final Client: Herself
description: Mary Lou Falcone is stepping out of the background to raise awareness of Lewy body dementia, the neurodegenerative disease that claimed her husband.
content: Mary Lou Falcone has lived most of her life away from the spotlight. “I made a conscious decision that I wanted to be behind the scenes,” she said over a recent lunch at Café Luxembourg, a few blocks from Lincoln Center on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Federal Investigators Widen Tesla Inquiry, Company Says
description: The Department of Justice has sought documents related to vehicle range and “personal benefits,” Tesla said.
content: The Department of Justice has expanded its inquiry into Tesla’s business practices to include how far its vehicles can travel on a full charge and “personal benefits” to high-ranking executives or large shareholders, the company said without elaborating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nicolson
title: How a Few Days Sailing in the Aegean Changed My Mind About the Fundamental Nature of Things
description: Philosophy has a geography.
content: A few years ago, my wife, Sarah, and I went on a sailing trip on the eastern Aegean. It was heaven: the two of us out at sea, charting a course between Greek islands and the coast of Turkey, taking turns helming the boat and dozing below, surrounded by all the glittering blue of the sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Mary Lou Retton Is Released From Hospital, Daughter Says
description: The former gymnast’s family said this month that Retton had been hospitalized with pneumonia and that she was “fighting for her life.”
content: Mary Lou Retton, the decorated Olympic gymnast, has been released from a hospital, one of her daughters said on Monday, about two weeks after her family reported that the gold medalist had a rare form of pneumonia and was in an intensive care unit “fighting for her life.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: They Wished to Be Buried in Israel. But They Died on the Eve of War.
description: Inside the complicated logistics of sending American Jews to cemeteries in the Holy Land.
content: Among the soldiers and volunteers heading to Israel from Kennedy Airport this month, as fighting raged in Gaza, were seven Jewish New Yorkers whose lifelong desires were being fulfilled. They were in seven coffins in the cargo hold of an El Al flight to Israel, where they would be buried.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: The Rock’s Wax Figure Will Get Redo, Museum Says
description: The Grévin Museum in Paris said it is “improving” a likeness of Dwayne Johnson that one online critic called “melanin deficient.”
content: A wax museum in Paris said it would change its recently unveiled statue of Dwayne Johnson, better known as the Rock, after a week of ridicule on social media and a plea from the actor himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Barry
title: Were the Fake Trump Signs a Prank? Or a Political Dirty Trick?
description: The placards were up in a wealthy town for less than a day. The fight over them lasted years.
content: The sudden sprouting of red-and-white campaign signs upended one autumn morning in the affluent Connecticut town of Greenwich. It was as if the valuable ground had been sprinkled overnight with political pixie dust.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper and Rory Smith
title: The Stratospheric Rise of Lionel Messi’s Pink Jersey
description: In the span of three months, the soccer superstar has made Inter Miami’s eye-catching jersey the hottest piece of sports merchandise on the planet.
content: All of a sudden, after a single summer, the pink jersey is everywhere. It has become almost impossible to acquire, yet there it is, paradoxically, on the backs of thousands of fans thronging American stadiums, hanging from market stalls in Buenos Aires and Bangkok, a vivid flash on almost every field where children gather to play soccer in England.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie Kozolchyk
title: Baaba Maal’s Dakar
description: The Senegalese singer-songwriter known as the “voice of Wakanda” from the “Black Panther” films recommends sites to see in the place where he found his own voice.
content: Had everything gone to plan, the singer-songwriter Baaba Maal’s move to Senegal’s capital from the northern hinterlands would have ended up differently — specifically, with a law degree. “When I first came to Dakar, I was supposed to study at the university because that was the wish of my parents,” he said, while a pair of sculptures, as if on cue, eyed him sternly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo and Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: At Least 7 Dead as ‘Super Fog’ Blankets New Orleans, Causing Pileups
description: The combination of marsh fire smoke and moisture in the air created what a meteorologist called a “perfect storm.” Low visibility contributed to the traffic accidents.
content: A dense “super fog” hovered over New Orleans on Monday, shrouding the area in an impenetrable mist that led to traffic pileups involving dozens of vehicles and leaving at least seven people dead, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: To Build Momentum, Scott Tackles Race and Racism in Chicago
description: Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina gave his speech as his struggling presidential campaign said it would move most of its staff to Iowa.
content: Senator Tim Scott, struggling to gain traction less than three months before the first Republican primary ballots are cast, came to the South Side of Chicago on Monday to rebuke the welfare state and the liberal politicians he dismissed as “drug dealers of despair.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Companies Are Caught in the Israel-Hamas War’s Crossfire
description: First it was college campuses. Now the corporate world is increasingly feeling pressure to find a balance in responding to the war.
content: As the Israel-Hamas war stretches on — with Israeli airstrikes hitting more targets in Gaza amid calls by the U.S. and others to delay a potential ground invasion — companies are finding themselves increasingly tangled in the conflict’s complex politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
title: Turkey’s President Sends Sweden’s NATO Bid to Parliament for Ratification
description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan had been holding out on approval of Sweden’s application. It’s unclear why he is now moving it forward.
content: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey on Monday signed and sent to Parliament a measure approving Sweden’s bid to join the NATO military alliance, according to a brief statement from his office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Donahue
title: If Everyone Gets an A, No One Gets an A
description: Grade inflation acts just like real inflation.
content: What is an “A,” anyway? Does it mean that a 16 year-old recognizes 96 percent of the allusions in “The Bluest Eye”? Or that she could tell you 95 percent of the reasons the Teapot Dome Scandal was so important? Or, just that she made it to most classes? Does it come from a physics teacher in the Great Smoky Mountains who bludgeons students with weekly, memory-taxing tests, or from a trigonometry teacher in Topeka who works in Taylor Swift references and allows infinite “re-tests”?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Why Do Women Still Wear Stilettos?
description: A reader wonders why the uncomfortable and often impractical shoes have not been retired.
content: It is true, the death knell of the stiletto — that high heel invented in the 1950s that is balanced on a knife point and raises the back of the foot, thus transforming the female silhouette in ways that seem tailored to the pleasures of the male gaze — turned out to have been highly exaggerated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: How to Win Your Next UNO Game
description: UNO domination isn’t just about Draw 2s, Skips and Reverses, but those cards definitely help.
content: On most days, Ray Adler, the global head of games for Mattel, carries a deck of UNO cards in his pocket, just in case someone might be up for a friendly round. The nice thing about the game, he said in an interview, is that it transcends language barriers and is familiar to just about everyone. Sitting down to a spontaneous game is a great way to break the ice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper, Adam Entous and Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Raises Concerns About Israel’s Plan of Action in Gaza, Officials Say
description: The Pentagon has sent officers to help the Israelis with the challenges of fighting an urban war.
content: The Biden administration is concerned that Israel lacks achievable military objectives in Gaza, and that the Israel Defense Forces are not yet ready to launch a ground invasion with a plan that can work, senior administration officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Plea Hearing Set for 2024 in Indonesian Bombings Case
description: Two Malaysian prisoners at Guantánamo Bay were charged in terrorist attacks in Bali and Jakarta that killed more than 200 people two decades ago.
content: A military judge at Guantánamo Bay on Monday scheduled a Jan. 15 plea hearing for two Malaysian prisoners who are accused of committing war crimes as accessories to deadly terrorist attacks in Indonesia two decades ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: plaudit
description: This word has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word plaudit has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 12 in “Michelin’s Coveted Stars Can Come With Some Costs” by Julia Moskin:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Do You Really Need to Shower Every Day?
description: There is no standard approach. Here’s how to figure out the right frequency for you.
content: If you feel the need to shower daily, you’re certainly not alone: In one 2021 survey of more than 5,700 U.S. adults, over 60 percent of the respondents said that they showered at least once each day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin P. Clarke
title: Why the World Is Watching Iran
description: As Iran rages over the mounting casualties in Gaza, fears are growing that its on-again-off-again proxy war with Israel will break out into a sustained conflict.
content: The Middle East could be on the verge of a regional conflagration. That’s in stark contrast to the atmosphere of just a few weeks ago, when the Biden administration was working on sealing a historic deal between Saudi Arabia and Israel that it hoped would stabilize a region long convulsed by war and sectarianism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Taylor Swift’s ‘Cruel Summer’ Hits No. 1 After Four Years
description: The song from Swift’s 2019 album, “Lover,” is a fan favorite that took on new life during her record-breaking Eras Tour. On the album chart, Bad Bunny debuts at the top.
content: Four years ago, Taylor Swift included the song “Cruel Summer” on her album “Lover.” It became a fan favorite, and had been in line to be released as a single in 2020, before the Covid-19 pandemic changed all plans. “That is something that happened that stopped ‘Cruel Summer’ from ever being a single,” the singer said a few months ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Gavin Newsom Wants to Export California’s Climate Laws to the World
description: The Democratic governor is supercharging climate policy and eyeing a future White House run. But critics say some of his constituents could be left behind.
content: Gavin Newsom, the California governor, packed his bags and his ambition Monday and flew to Chinese provinces on a weeklong mission to negotiate climate agreements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: ‘I Have Your Back’: Doug Emhoff Draws on His Faith After Hamas Attack
description: Mr. Emhoff, the husband of Kamala Harris, is the first Jewish spouse of a president or vice president. He has focused on providing comfort to people in pain after the Hamas attack.
content: Doug Emhoff has spent the weeks after the Hamas attack on Israel acting as a touchstone for some of the anguish, fear and anger felt by Jewish Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: U.A.W. Expands Strike to a Ram Plant in Michigan
description: The United Automobile Workers union called on 6,800 workers to walk off the job at a large factory that makes one of Stellantis’s most profitable vehicles.
content: In a major escalation of its six-week strike at the three large U.S. automakers, the United Automobile Workers union on Monday told 6,800 workers at a large Ram pickup truck plant in Michigan to walk off the job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mustafa Hussain and Benjamin Hoffman
title: Chicago’s Newest Must-Have Fashion Accessory
description: Before Connor Bedard had taken the ice for the Blackhawks, the 18-year-old hockey phenom’s No. 98 jersey had already taken over the Windy City, and beyond.
content: Before Connor Bedard had laced up his skates for a regular season game, the 18-year-old hockey phenom had already caused a surge in the Chicago Blackhawks’ season ticket sales. He had fans talking about a return to glory for a team that had fallen on hard times. And he was drawing audacious comparisons to some of the sport’s greatest stars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Administration Moves to Ban a Solvent Linked to Cancer
description: The chemical, trichloroethylene, is used in some adhesives and cleaning products.
content: The Biden administration has proposed to ban all uses of trichloroethylene, an industrial solvent used in glues, other adhesives, spot removers and metal cleaners, saying exposure to even small amounts can cause cancer, damage to the central nervous system and other health effects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: ‘Persons of Interest’ Identified in Killing of Detroit Synagogue Leader, Police Say
description: The city’s police chief emphasized that the attack did not appear to be related to antisemitism. No arrests have been made.
content: The authorities in Detroit said on Monday that they had identified “some persons of interest” in the killing of Samantha Woll, 40, the president of a downtown synagogue who was found stabbed to death outside her home early Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: 92NY Halts Literary Series After Pulling Author Critical of Israel
description: The organization put the series on pause after several writers withdrew from events to protest its decision not to hold a reading last week with an author who had criticized Israel.
content: 92NY, one of the city’s leading cultural organizations, announced Monday that it was putting its prestigious literary reading series on pause, following an outcry over its decision to cancel an appearance last week by a prominent writer who had been critical of Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Aleksei Navalny Forcibly Removed From Jail Cell After Protest
description: The Russian opposition leader had refused to leave his cell in protest after prison authorities took his writing tools, allies say.
content: The Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny was forcibly removed from his cell by law enforcement officers on Monday after he had refused to leave it to protest a decision by prison authorities to take away his writing tools, his political allies said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and Natalie Alcoba
title: 5 Takeaways from Argentina’s Election
description: Javier Milei, a libertarian economist often compared to Donald Trump, will face off against Sergio Massa, Argentina’s economy minister, in a runoff next month.
content: After two votes, Argentina’s presidential race now heads into its decisive round with the final two political survivors vying to lead a country where people are desperate for a financial turnaround.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss and Stanley Reed
title: Chevron to Acquire Hess for $53 Billion in Latest Major Oil Deal
description: The acquisition marks further consolidation of the oil industry and highlights the confidence that energy companies have in the future of fossil fuels.
content: In the second energy megadeal this month, Chevron, the second-largest U.S. oil giant, said Monday that it had agreed to acquire Hess, a medium-size rival, in an all-stock deal valued at $53 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Who Is Jackson Mahomes, and Why Are Swifties Concerned?
description: Taylor Swift spent Sunday’s game in Kansas City, Mo., in a suite with Mr. Mahomes, an influencer known for problematic behavior and a sexual battery arrest.
content: As Taylor Swift and Brittany Mahomes, the wife of Patrick Mahomes, quarterback of the Kansas City Chiefs, slapped hands and bumped hips in a touchdown celebration that took over social media on Sunday night, a man in a white T-shirt and a backward baseball cap clapped behind them. The handshake, which was shown during the broadcast of a game between the Kansas City Chiefs and the Los Angeles Chargers, finished with both women turning around and celebrating with the man, who bent down to their level with a broad smile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: California Boosts Minimum Wage for Health Care and Fast-Food Workers
description: Sector-specific pay bumps are a new twist in a state that already has one of the highest hourly minimum wages in the nation.
content: It’s Monday. California is raising minimum wages for health care workers and fast-food workers. Plus, striking actors and the Hollywood studios say they’re restarting negotiations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: The People Who Broke the House
description: As the House speaker crisis drags on into a fourth week, a look at some of the Republicans who have mired the country in this mess.
content: When it comes to Congress, Americans have come to expect a certain baseline of dysfunction. But I think most of us can agree that the current House Republican majority is something special. Overthrowing a speaker for the first time in history. Rejecting multiple nominees to replace him. Members publicly trashing one another. One faction’s supporters threatening opposing members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: Review: The Great Emerson String Quartet Takes Its Final Bow
description: A pillar of chamber music for nearly a half-century, the Emerson players bid farewell with Beethoven’s Opus 130 and Schubert’s String Quintet.
content: Farewell to the Emerson String Quartet, a group that has beaten at the heart of chamber music in the United States, and far beyond, for almost half a century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $900,000 Homes in California
description: A 1927 bungalow in Oakland, a two-bedroom condominium in Los Angeles and a mobile home in Agoura Hills.
content: This house is on the north side of the city, about 10 minutes from downtown Oakland and from the center of Berkeley. It is a five-minute walk from the baseball fields and indoor basketball courts at Charles Porter Golden Gate Recreation Center and within walking distance of a record store and a bakery on nearby Alcatraz Avenue. A brewery, a coffee shop and a sushi restaurant are on San Pablo Avenue, a few blocks away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Monday Briefing
description: Fears of a wider Middle East conflict.
content: Israeli authorities said yesterday they were expanding a state-funded plan to evacuate residents from 14 additional villages near the border with Lebanon, as conflict intensified in the area. Escalating clashes on the border, along with strikes in Syria and in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, have intensified fears of a widening regional conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elsa Dixler
title: Natalie Zemon Davis, Historian of the Marginalized, Dies at 94
description: She wrote of peasants, unsung women, border crossers and, most popularly, Martin Guerre, a 16th-century village impostor recalled in a 1980s movie.
content: Natalie Zemon Davis, a social and cultural historian whose imaginative and deeply researched investigations of the lives of marginalized figures — peasants, long-forgotten women, border crossers of all sorts — profoundly influenced the discipline, died on Saturday at her home in Toronto. She was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Hamas Released Two More Hostages
description: Also, Stephen Sondheim’s last musical opens in New York. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: Hamas released two women who were taken hostage by the Palestinian group during its Oct. 7 attack on Israel. The Red Cross confirmed their release, saying that it had helped to transfer the women out of Gaza this evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: Years Late, a Young Pianist Finally Gets to Carnegie
description: Alexandre Kantorow made his Carnegie Hall recital debut after winning both the International Tchaikovsky Competition and the Gilmore Artist Award.
content: The French pianist Alexandre Kantorow was supposed to make his Carnegie Hall recital debut on March 25, 2020, as a late replacement for the ailing Murray Perahia. We know what happened with that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Editors’ Note: Gaza Hospital Coverage
description: The Times’s initial accounts of the blast attributed the claim of Israeli responsibility to Palestinian officials, and noted that the Israeli military said it was investigating the blast. However, the early versions of the coverage relied too heavily on claims by Hamas.
content: On Oct. 17, The New York Times published news of an explosion at a hospital in Gaza City, leading its coverage with claims by Hamas government officials that an Israeli airstrike was the cause and that hundreds of people were dead or injured. The report included a large headline at the top of The Times’s website.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Thurston Moore Revisits His Sonic Youth
description: In a new memoir, the rock luminary details his long career and the music that shaped him.
content: The loudest summoning gong in pop culture history, if dozens of rock memoirs can be believed, was struck on Sept. 9, 1956. That is when Elvis performed on “The Ed Sullivan Show.” But time passed. Patti Smith’s revelatory moment came eight years later, when she saw the Rolling Stones on Sullivan. The band made her feel she was “trapped in a field of hot dots.” The music gave her a funny feeling, she wrote, in her pants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai and Jenny Gross
title: Women in Iceland to ‘Take the Day Off’ in Protest of Gender Inequality
description: The one-day strike on Tuesday is expected to be the largest walkout by women in the Nordic nation since 1975. Even the prime minister said she would take part.
content: Tens of thousands of women and nonbinary people in Iceland were expected to participate on Tuesday in a one-day strike, which organizers called the country’s largest effort to protest workplace inequality in nearly five decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Menendez Pleads Not Guilty to Plotting to Be an Agent of Egypt
description: Senator Robert Menendez, a Democrat, was arraigned on Monday in Manhattan federal court. It was his second appearance there in a month.
content: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey pleaded not guilty on Monday to a new federal charge that accused him of illegally plotting to be an agent of Egypt while serving as chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: The U.K. Wants a Cheaper Way to Handle Migrants. But Not This One.
description: Britain tested an alternative to detention for people living outside the immigration system. Though praised by the U.N., its outcomes didn’t fit the government’s hard-line approach.
content: At the age of 13, she came to England from Nigeria with her relatives for what she thought was a summer vacation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: With War in Israel, the Cancel Culture Debate Comes Full Circle
description: We’re in an especially repressive period for free speech.
content: Nathan Thrall’s searing new book, “A Day in the Life of Abed Salama,” struck me as important even before the obscene massacres and mass kidnappings committed by Hamas this month lit the Middle East on fire. Today, with people still struggling to understand the contours of this deeply complicated conflict, the book seems essential.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelia Herrera
title: Trance Music Is Coming Back. Evian Christ Is Part of the Revival.
description: The producer got his start in the 2010s connecting underground electronic sounds and hip-hop. His first album, “Revanchist,” embraces a long-derided genre of dance music.
content: It was the seventh soggy weekend in a row in New York, but a throng of 20-something club kids with chunky boots and shaggy mullets still made the pilgrimage to a punk venue in an industrial stretch of Brooklyn where the British producer Evian Christ was performing a four-hour D.J. set to celebrate the release of his debut album, “Revanchist.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne and Natalie Proulx
title: Do Schools Need to Do More to Hold Students Accountable?
description: Teachers are reporting that pressure from snowplow parents and bad district policies are making their jobs harder. Is it too easy for students to get by at your school?
content: Do you think your school does enough to hold all students accountable academically and behaviorally?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: When Google Search Reveals Too Much
description: “One glimpse at my boyfriend’s recent searches caused our already precarious relationship to topple.”
content: In the most recent Modern Love essay, “When Your Search History Says What You Can’t,” Kassia Oset shares a cautionary tale of the heart and the browser.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Writers Guild Faces Backlash for Not Condemning Hamas Attack
description: A union leader told members that the board’s viewpoints were varied and that a consensus could not be reached.
content: Just weeks after the Writers Guild of America displayed solidarity by ending a monthslong strike and voting overwhelmingly in favor of a new contract with the major entertainment companies, the union is being roiled by a fight over its lack of a public statement condemning the Hamas attack on Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Regan Stephens, Nikita Richardson, Brett Anderson, Priya Krishna and Sara Bonisteel
title: The 25 Best Restaurants in Philadelphia Right Now
description: The dining scene here is having a moment, whether it’s outstanding pizza, fiery Ethiopian fried chicken or French inflected cuisine that feels like a cozy dinner party.
content: In the Where to Eat: 25 Best series, we’re highlighting our favorite restaurants in cities across the United States. These lists will be updated as restaurants close and open, and as we find new gems to recommend. As always, we pay for all of our meals and don’t accept free items.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Leftist Upstart Threatens to Shake Up German Politics
description: Sahra Wagenknecht has announced a new party, which could become another populist force scrambling German politics.
content: Germany’s political landscape has been fracturing for a decade or more as traditional parties lose ground to populist elements, forcing the establishment of a three-way coalition government for the first time in the country’s modern history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Jim Tankersley
title: A Push for Tech Hubs in Overlooked Places Picks 31 to Vie for Money
description: A new federal program will be a test of whether spreading funds outside of big cities will result in economic gains, or in inefficiencies.
content: The Biden administration said on Monday that it had chosen 31 regions as potential recipients of federal money that would seek to fund innovation in parts of the country that government investment overlooked in the past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: In ‘Seafood Simple,’ Eric Ripert Includes Techniques and Not-So-Simple Recipes
description: Cream puff decorating classes for the holidays, a Phony Mezcal Negroni from St. Agrestis and more food news.
content: Eric Ripert’s previous cookbook, “Vegetable Simple,” lived up to its title with some recipes needing but two or three ingredients. His new book, “Seafood Simple”? Not so simple. Effortless wonders include salmon and tomato à la Gilbert (for Gilbert Le Coze, a founder of Le Bernardin, who Mr. Ripert succeeded as an owner and the executive chef), a crispy black bass Basquaise, a pristine scallop ceviche, and a quick toss of shrimp, sweet garlic and extra-virgin olive oil. There are more demanding dishes worth tackling: monkfish Bourride with aioli and skate with sambal. Halibut with warm herb vinaigrette, which is based on an original Le Bernardin preparation, requires not just a vinaigrette, but a velouté, the secret to the dish’s success  — and something I wish I’d known when I tried to replicate it at home years ago. The recipe chapters are divided according to techniques, nine of them. The book begins with step-by-step photos of preparing seafood, including filleting, shucking, skinning and so forth. Shopping and storage tips are included.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Aaron Boxerman
title: Hamas Fails to Make Case That Israel Struck Hospital
description: A senior Hamas official says “nothing is left” of the munition that hit the Ahli Arab hospital in Gaza City last week, killing hundreds. Israel says the explosion was caused by a misfired Palestinian rocket.
content: Six days after Hamas accused Israel of bombing a hospital in Gaza City and killing hundreds of people, the armed Palestinian group has yet to produce or describe any evidence linking Israel to the strike, says it cannot find the munition that hit the site and has declined to provide detail to support its count of the casualties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandeep Jauhar
title: My Father Didn’t Want to Live if He Had Dementia. But Then He Had It.
description: It is hard to know in advance what kind of existence you’ll be content with.
content: Two years ago, when my father was dying of dementia, my siblings and I faced a terrible dilemma: Whose wishes for his medical treatment were we to honor? Those of my father back when he was a healthy, highly functioning geneticist? Or those of the simpler, weakened man my father had become?
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Oct. 23, 2023
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Oct. 23, 2023.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saif Hasnat
title: Train Collision in Bangladesh Leaves at Least 17 Dead
description: The accident, between a passenger train and a freight train, also injured over 100 people.
content: At least 17 people were killed when a passenger train and a freight train collided outside Bangladesh’s capital, Dhaka, during a busy holiday season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Leily Nikounazar
title: Iranian Teenager Reported Brain Dead by State Media
description: What happened to Armita Geravand, who entered a subway car and was carried out minutes later, is unclear. But her case evoked parallels to that of Mahsa Amini.
content: Armita Geravand, the Iranian girl who was dragged out of a subway car unconscious shortly after entering with her hair uncovered, has been pronounced brain dead, Iran’s state-owned media reported on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Zoglin
title: When Siskel and Ebert Were the Names Above the Title
description: In “Opposable Thumbs,” Matt Singer recalls the risky business of putting newspaper movie critics on TV — and the “combustible chemistry” that made it a hit.
content: They were known, a little unfairly, as “The Bald One” and “The Fat One.” Their most famous contribution to American culture was the reductive “thumbs up/thumbs down” verdict they gave to movies. But for more than two decades, Gene Siskel and Roger Ebert did something that seems remarkable in retrospect: These two ink-stained critics turned their debates over movies into must-see television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kashmir Hill
title: Face Search Engine PimEyes Blocks Searches of Children’s Faces
description: The change came in response to worries that the service could be used nefariously by a stranger.
content: Concerns about children’s privacy have led PimEyes, the public face search engine, to ban searches of minors. The PimEyes chief executive, Giorgi Gobronidze, who is based in Tbilisi, Georgia, said that technical measures had been put in place to block such searches as part of a “no harm policy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Developing World Sees Double Standard in West’s Actions in Gaza and Ukraine
description: Resentments are complicating calls by the Biden administration to rally the world against efforts to “annihilate” democracies.
content: For 20 months, the Biden administration has attempted to stake out the moral high ground against Russia, condemning its brutal war on Ukraine for indiscriminately killing civilians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: Gutting American Cuisine
description: In “Endangered Eating,” the food historian Sarah Lohman explores the onetime staples disappearing from our tables.
content: In Nashville, there’s a precisely conceived country restaurant called Audrey, which the chef Sean Brock named after his Appalachian grandmother. His menu is an exercise in the theory that in order to save food on the brink of extinction, you must eat it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel Shares Raw Footage of the Oct. 7 Attacks
description: The Israeli military showed the compilation to foreign reporters on a day when Israel continued to bombard Gaza with heavy airstrikes.
content: Bloodied corpses lying in a bedroom, a bathroom, on the roads by their cars. An emergency medical worker pouring mineral water from a bottle to douse the smoldering remains of charred bodies. A dead baby whose body bore signs of violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: Flight of the Drones Lights Up Central Park
description: The Drift collaborative orchestrated a performance art piece with light-emitting drones that mimic swarming starlings or fish — but mostly slow-motion fireworks.
content: It began with a sudden, breathtaking emergence over the trees to the south — a thousand points of blue light that expanded and dispersed into the sky. They organized into a kind of butterfly formation and set off in a northerly direction — and then the flotilla vanished, as if at the flip of a switch. Several beats later, it reappeared, to loud oohs and aahs from the crowd, as a stunning grid of white, pink and ruby luminosity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William B. Davis, Madison Dong, John Keefe, Judson Jones and Bea Malsky
title: Tracking Tropical Storm Otis
description: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Otis.
content: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Otis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: When Campaign Cash Withers
description: When campaign coffers dry up, candidates are sometimes forced to scale back their operations — or pull the plug.
content: When campaign coffers dry up, candidates are sometimes forced to scale back their operations — or pull the plug.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller and Francesca Paris
title: New SAT Data Highlights the Deep Inequality at the Heart of American Education
description: The differences in how rich and poor children are educated start very early.
content: The differences in how rich and poor children are educated start very early.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allison McCann
title: As Abortion Access Shrinks, Hospitals Fill in the Gaps
description: Hospitals are playing a growing role in abortion access, as pregnant women with certain health issues travel to seek care that clinics can’t provide.
content: Hospitals are playing a growing role in abortion access, as pregnant women with certain health issues travel to seek care that clinics can’t provide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Do You Recognize These Passages From Classic Books?
description: This short quiz challenges you to identify memorable lines from five novels.
content: This short quiz challenges you to identify memorable lines from five novels.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the document
description: In the first three bullets of this document there is a comparison to a drug cartel.
content: In the first three bullets of this document there is a comparison to a drug cartel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Kelso
title: Israel Intensifies Airstrikes on Gaza
description: The increased strikes across Gaza came amid international efforts to move humanitarian aid into the besieged territory.
content: The increased strikes across Gaza came amid international efforts to move humanitarian aid into the besieged territory.
source.name: The New York Times
